articles.headline: Even Google and Facebook May Face an Ad Slump
articles.snippet: Though ad sales at the two companies are expected to be down, they are likely to fare better than smaller peers and publishers.
articles.abstract: Though ad sales at the two companies are expected to be down, they are likely to fare better than smaller peers and publishers.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Google’s and Facebook’s advertising businesses, which have roughly tripled in combined size over the last five years, may be headed for a rare stumble as the coronavirus pushes the global economy into a tailspin.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Tiffany Hsu and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Big Banks, Readying for a Recession, Set Aside Billions
articles.snippet: First-quarter earnings reports from JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo showed the country’s largest banks were preparing for customer pain.
articles.abstract: First-quarter earnings reports from JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo showed the country’s largest banks were preparing for customer pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic shutdown the coronavirus has caused has already forced millions of Americans out of work and threatened the future of thousands of small businesses, and the country’s biggest banks are bracing for the fallout.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Predicts Worst Downturn Since the Great Depression
articles.snippet: The global economy is expected to contract by 3 percent this year as quarantines and lockdowns cripple output.
articles.abstract: The global economy is expected to contract by 3 percent this year as quarantines and lockdowns cripple output.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund issued a stark warning on Tuesday about the coronavirus’s economic toll, saying that the world is facing its worst downturn since the Great Depression as shuttered factories, quarantines and national lockdowns cause economic output to collapse.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Some European Nations Ease Pandemic Rules, but Move Warily
articles.snippet: The lifting of restrictions is an early test of whether democracies can restart their economies and restore basic freedoms without refueling the spread of the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: The lifting of restrictions is an early test of whether democracies can restart their economies and restore basic freedoms without refueling the spread of the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Slowly, tentatively, a handful of European countries began lifting constraints on daily life this week for the first time since the start of the coronavirus crisis, providing an early litmus test of whether Western democracies can gingerly restart their economies and restore basic freedoms without reviving the spread of the disease.

articles.headline: Crippled Airline Industry to Get $25 Billion Bailout, Part of It as Loans
articles.snippet: Airlines will receive billions of dollars in grants and loans to pay flight attendants, pilots and other employees.
articles.abstract: Airlines will receive billions of dollars in grants and loans to pay flight attendants, pilots and other employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has reached an agreement in principle with major airlines over the terms of a $25 billion bailout to prop up an industry hobbled by the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: U.S. Governors, at Center of Virus Response, Weigh What It Will Take to Reopen States
articles.snippet: Many governors say science will guide when they will allow a reopening, a choice they say belongs to them. “Normal it will not be,” Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said.
articles.abstract: Many governors say science will guide when they will allow a reopening, a choice they say belongs to them. “Normal it will not be,” Gov. Gavin Newsom of California said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In Oregon, Gov. Kate Brown said the move toward reopening her state would be a cautious and incremental one, guided by data on transmission of the coronavirus, availability of personal protective equipment and testing capacity, among other factors.

articles.headline: Trump’s Claim of Total Authority in Crisis Is Rejected Across Ideological Lines
articles.snippet: Trading barbs with governors about their powers over when to ease restrictions on society, the president made an assertion that lacks a basis in the Constitution or federal law.
articles.abstract: Trading barbs with governors about their powers over when to ease restrictions on society, the president made an assertion that lacks a basis in the Constitution or federal law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s claim that he wielded “total” authority in the pandemic crisis prompted rebellion not just from governors. Legal scholars across the ideological spectrum on Tuesday rejected his declaration that ultimately he, not state leaders, will decide when to risk lifting social distancing limits in order to reopen businesses.

articles.headline: After Coronavirus, Colleges Worry: Will Students Come Back?
articles.snippet: The pandemic has already cost universities millions of dollars. As they consider the possibility of remote classes into the fall, they’re worried about losing students, too.
articles.abstract: The pandemic has already cost universities millions of dollars. As they consider the possibility of remote classes into the fall, they’re worried about losing students, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Claire McCarville dreamed of going to college in New York or Los Angeles, and was thrilled last month to get accepted to selective schools in both places. But earlier this month, she sent a $300 deposit to Arizona State University, a 15-minute drive from her home in Phoenix. “It made more sense,” she said, “in light of the virus.”

articles.headline: Shoulder-to-Shoulder, These Detroit Workers Have No Choice but to Ride the Bus
articles.snippet: Some people can do their best to socially distance. But there’s no distance on a city bus full of people who, virus or no virus, have to get to work.
articles.abstract: Some people can do their best to socially distance. But there’s no distance on a city bus full of people who, virus or no virus, have to get to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Paris Banks sprayed the seat with Lysol before sliding into the last row on the right. Rochell Brown put out her cigarette, tucked herself behind the steering wheel and slapped the doors shut.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Emily Rose Bennett

articles.headline: States Are in a Quandary as Taxes Evaporate and Virus Spending Soars
articles.snippet: With businesses closed and obligations mounting, state governments are looking at a mix of remedies.
articles.abstract: With businesses closed and obligations mounting, state governments are looking at a mix of remedies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ballooning costs of the coronavirus pandemic have put an unexpected strain on the finances of states, which are hurriedly diverting funds from elsewhere to fight the outbreak even as the economic shutdown squeezes their main source of revenue — taxes.

articles.headline: ‘Pretty Catastrophic’ Month for Retailers, and Now a Race to Survive
articles.snippet: March brought a record sales plunge as the coronavirus outbreak closed stores. A long shutdown could leave lasting changes in the shopping landscape.
articles.abstract: March brought a record sales plunge as the coronavirus outbreak closed stores. A long shutdown could leave lasting changes in the shopping landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: Retail sales plunged in March, offering a grim snapshot of the coronavirus outbreak’s effect on consumer spending, as businesses shuttered from coast to coast and wary shoppers restricted their spending.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Ben Casselman
